messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Ban Dainagon stuff
messages.msgSnippet: It is fun, which is why I threw it out there. My own feelings are that the nerikawa-tsuba were probably more expensive. But this is pure speculation. G ...
messages.messageBody:
It is fun, which is why I threw it out there. My own feelings are that the
nerikawa-tsuba were probably more expensive. But this is pure speculation.

G
-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Tuesday, May 06, 2003 9:28 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ban Dainagon stuff


Funny that you mentioned it, I was thinking about the same thing today. I
first wondered if maybe a drop in the cost of iron production was
responsible for the later proliferation of iron tsuba. But when you look at
the list of individuals who gave their tachi to Oyamazumi, they could
obviously afford whatever they wanted on their swords. These are rather
undecorated mounts, so I'd guess that there was some perceived functional
advantage rather than just a display of status and/or aesthetics at play.

I'd also guess that the nerikawa tsuba took more time and labor to make
(curing, soaking, gluing, drying...fitting a fukurin...). Iron guards were
probably quicker to make, but the cost of the material (including fuel)
would be higher. It'd take some research into the economies of the time to
figure out and answer.

I'd guess that kawa would also be expensive in the sense that it'd need to
be replaced more frequently than iron. Getting a tsuba made of it wet would
not be a good idea, for example. It may be that the durability of iron is
what made it more attractive for the lower status mounts.

Speculation sure is fun...
Jim



I wonder what the cost
of a lacquered leather tsuba would be in relation to an iron disk during
Heian and Kamakura?

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.msgSnippet: Funny that you mentioned it, I was thinking about the same thing today.  I first wondered if maybe a drop in the cost of iron production was responsible for
messages.messageBody:
Funny that you mentioned it, I was thinking about the same thing today. I first wondered if maybe a drop in the cost of iron production was responsible for the later proliferation of iron tsuba. But when you look at the list of individuals who gave their tachi to Oyamazumi, they could obviously afford whatever they wanted on their swords. These are rather undecorated mounts, so I'd guess that there was some perceived functional advantage rather than just a display of status and/or aesthetics at play.

I'd also guess that the nerikawa tsuba took more time and labor to make (curing, soaking, gluing, drying...fitting a fukurin...). Iron guards were probably quicker to make, but the cost of the material (including fuel) would be higher. It'd take some research into the economies of the time to figure out and answer.

I'd guess that kawa would also be expensive in the sense that it'd need to be replaced more frequently than iron. Getting a tsuba made of it wet would not be a good idea, for example. It may be that the durability of iron is what made it more attractive for the lower status mounts.

Speculation sure is fun...
Jim



I wonder what the cost
of a lacquered leather tsuba would be in relation to an iron disk during
Heian and Kamakura?

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Ban Dainagon stuff
messages.msgSnippet: Infact it would not surprise me if the leather tsuba was more expensive at the time than the iron disk............... - Matt ... Van: Gordon Robson
messages.messageBody:
Infact it would not surprise me if the leather tsuba was more expensive
at the time than the iron disk...............

- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Gordon Robson [mailto:robsongo@...]
Verzonden: dinsdag 6 mei 2003 1:22
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: RE: [nihontostudy] Ban Dainagon stuff


And yes, who knows what kind of tsuba was on there. I wonder what the
cost
of a lacquered leather tsuba would be in relation to an iron disk during
Heian and Kamakura?
-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Tuesday, May 06, 2003 7:24 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ban Dainagon stuff


By the way, Hatori Jiichiro published the uchigatana and koshigatana
details from Ban Dainagon in his book "Tsuba no Bunkashi" in 1969 (page
26).
That was ten years before Sasano did the same in "Tosogu no Kigen."
Jim

For those who haven't seen the book, the best detail online from the
Ban
Dainagon I've found so far is here:

http://www.kyohaku.go.jp/gakuso/gakuso02/gs2a28ie.htm

Look at the fellow in the upper left hand corner. He is carrying an
uchigatana with a tsuba, however it's rather difficult to say whether it
might be made of iron, yamagane or leather.

Gordon - do you have any sort of image of the nagamaki tsuba? Is it
a
plain iron plate without sukashi?

Jim

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Ban Dainagon stuff
messages.msgSnippet: It is a perfectly round disk with no sukashi. I will see about doing a scan and trying a post. I m at work now so I will have to try tomorrow. I will also
messages.messageBody:
It is a perfectly round disk with no sukashi. I will see about doing a scan
and trying a post. I'm at work now so I will have to try tomorrow. I will
also check the text to see if there is an attempt at giving it a date. Based
on the size and rusting, I would say late Kamakura to Nambokucho. Sasano did
not mention what blade, if any, it was on.

G
